featured.text: “Why should a person need a fork when God had given him hands?” they asked.
From the 10th through the 13th centuries, forks were fairly common among the wealthy in Byzantium.
In late 17th century France, larger forks with four curved tines were developed.
Forks at that time were fairly large with two tines that aided in the carving of meat in the kitchen.

By the 7th century A.D., royal courts of the Middle East began to use forks at the table for dining.
In the 11th century, a Byzantine wife brought forks to Italy; however, they were not widely adopted there until the 16th century.
The history of using forks for dining.
The French were also slow to accept forks, for using them was thought to be awkward.
By the early 19th century, four-tined forks had also been developed in Germany and England and slowly began to spread to America.
